text:
Think about how this might apply in your own life.  

Have you ever become trapped reliving past mistakes?  

It’s like a video player stuck on endless replay.  

Do you spend time and energy worrying about the future?  

Do you think more about things you can’t control?  

Rather than focusing on what you can control?  

Do you find yourself busy preparing for the next meeting?  

Or the next assignment or the next chapter in your life?  

Instead of being fully present in the current one?  

It’s natural to obsess over past mistakes.  

It’s also common to feel stress about what may come.  

Yet every second spent worrying distracts us from now.  

The ancient Greeks had two words for time.  

The first was chronos.  

The second was kairos.  

The Greek god Chronos was imagined as an elderly man.  

His name connotes the literal ticking clock.  

It refers to chronological time we measure.  

Kairos is different.  

It refers to time that is opportune and right.  

Chronos is quantitative; kairos is qualitative.  

Kairos is experienced only when we are fully in the moment.  

We only ever have now.  

We can’t control the future in a literal sense.  

We can only control the now.  

Of course, we learn from the past.  

We can imagine the future.  

Yet we can only execute in the here and now.  

Nonessentialists focus on past successes and failures.  

They also think about future challenges and opportunities.  

They miss the present moment.  

They become distracted and unfocused.  

They aren’t really there.  

The way of the Essentialist is to tune into the present.  

To experience life in kairos, not just chronos.  

To focus on what is truly important.  

Not yesterday or tomorrow, but right now.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Focusing on the present moment is essential for effectively engaging with what truly matters in life.
